definitions.definition: a lawyer who prepares legal documents, for example for the sale of land or buildings, advises people on legal matters, and can speak for them in some courts of law
definitions.labels: (British English)North American EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American English

examples.text: Her first step was to contact a solicitor for advice.
I discussed the matter with my instructing solicitor.
She is still a practising solicitor at the age of sixty-two.
There will be no court duty solicitor today.
Bridge joined the firm as a trainee solicitor.
Mr Andrew Davis, solicitor for the Jones family, read a statement.

definitions.definition: a person whose job is to visit or phone people and try to sell them something
the most senior legal officer of a city, town or government department

wordOrigin: late Middle English (denoting an agent or deputy): from Old French solliciteur, from solliciter, from Latin sollicitare ‘agitate’, from sollicitus ‘anxious’, from sollus ‘entire’ + citus (past participle of ciere ‘set in motion’).
